{{about|the song|the album|In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida (album)|the video|In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida (video)}} {{Infobox song | name = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | cover = Inagaddadavida-single.jpeg | alt = | caption = Cover of the 1968 German single | type = single | artist = [[Iron Butterfly]] | album = [[In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida (album)|In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida]] | B-side = Iron Butterfly Theme | released = {{Start date|1968|06|14}} | format = [[Gramophone record|7-inch]] | recorded = {{unbulleted list|May 27, 1968|Ultrasonic Studios, [[Hempstead (village), New York|Hempstead]], [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]]}} | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Acid rock]]{{cite book|author1=Ray Broadus Browne|author2=Pat Browne|title=The Guide to United States Popular Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U3rJxPYT32MC&pg=PA431|year=2001|publisher=Popular Press|isbn=978-0-87972-821-2|page=431}}|[[psychedelic rock]]{{cite book|author=Robert Dimery|title=1001 Songs: You Must Hear Before You Die|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UH_EOUR4tmkC&pg=PT1076|date=5 December 2011|publisher=Octopus|isbn=978-1-84403-717-9|page=1076}}|[[hard rock]]{{cite book|title=The Avant-garde and American Postmodernity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hv00wyBJ_e0C|publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi|isbn=978-1-61703-490-9|page=177}}|[[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]]{{cite book|author1=William Phillips|author2=Brian Cogan|title=Encyclopedia of Heavy Metal Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=52hFCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA117|date=20 March 2009|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-34801-3|page=117}}|[[occult rock]]{{cite book |last1=Horror Revival |first1=Folk |title=Folk Horror Revival: Harvest Hymns. Volume I- Twisted Roots |page=55}}}} | length = {{unbulleted list|{{Duration|m=17|s=05}} {{small|(album version)}}|{{Duration|m=2|s=52}} {{small|(single version)}}}} | label = [[Atco Records|Atco]] | writer = [[Doug Ingle]] | producer = Jim Hilton | prev_title = Possession | prev_year = 1968 | next_title = Soul Experience | next_year = 1969 | misc = {{Extra music sample | type = single | filename = Iron Butterfly In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida Riff.ogg | title = "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida" }} }} "'''In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida'''" (mistransliteration: "In the Garden of Eden") is a song recorded by [[Iron Butterfly]] and written by bandmember [[Doug Ingle]], released on their 1968 album ''[[In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida (album)|In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida]]''. At slightly over 17 minutes, it occupies the entire second side of the ''In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida'' album. The [[lyrics]] are simple, and heard only at the beginning and the end. The track was recorded at Ultrasonic Studios in [[Hempstead (village), New York|Hempstead]], [[Long Island]], New York. In 2009, it was named the 24th-greatest hard rock song of all time by [[VH1]].{{cite web|url=http://music.spreadit.org/vh1-top-100-hard-rock-songs/ |title=Vh1 Top 100 Hard Rock Songs |publisher=Spreadit.org |accessdate=December 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212180319/http://music.spreadit.org/vh1-top-100-hard-rock-songs/ |archivedate=February 12, 2009 |df= }} It is also often regarded as an influence on heavy metal music and one of the firsts of the genre.{{cite book |author= Various (Alfred Publishing Staff)|date= 2007|title= The Complete Idiot's Guide to Rock Guitar Songs |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=3SphIgOuzkcC&pg=PA86&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false |location= |publisher= Alfred Publishing |page= |isbn= 978-0739046289 |access-date= }}{{cite book |last= Phillips |first= William |date= 2008 |title= Encyclopedia of Heavy Metal Music |url= |location= |publisher= Greenwood Press |page= 117 |isbn= 978-0313348006 |access-date= }} The song was featured in the ''[[Seinfeld]]'' episode "[[The Slicer (Seinfeld)|The Slicer]]", ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Bart Sells His Soul]]" and the ''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]'' episode "[[Flying Sauces]]". ==Background== Though it was not recorded until their second album, "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida" was written during Iron Butterfly's early days. According to drummer [[Ron Bushy]], organist/vocalist [[Doug Ingle]] wrote the song one evening while drinking an entire [[gallon]] of [[Red Mountain AVA|Red Mountain]] wine. When the inebriated Ingle then played the song for Bushy, who wrote down the lyrics for him, he was slurring his words so badly that what was supposed to be "in the Garden of Eden" was interpreted by Bushy as "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida".{{Cite AV media notes |title=Iron Butterfly: Live at the Galaxy 1967 |year=2014 |first=Dave |last=Thompson |author-link=Dave Thompson (author) |type=Liner notes |publisher=Purple Pyramid Records}}{{cite web |url=http://www.catalogs.com/info/bestof/top-10-drum-solos-of-all-time |title=Top 10 Drum Solos of All Time |website=Catalogs.com |date=October 24, 2011 |accessdate=6 June 2017}} Even though nearly all of Iron Butterfly's songs were quite structured, the idea of turning the minute-and-a-half long ballad into an extended jam emerged very early; [[Jeff Beck]] claims that when he saw Iron Butterfly perform at the Galaxy Club in April 1967, half a year before the band recorded their first album, their entire second set consisted of a 35-minute long version of "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida". ==Edited versions== {{unreferenced|section|date=September 2014}} "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida" was released as a 45 rpm single in the US and other territories. The 17-minute original version was edited down to 2:53. This version contains the intro, two complete verses, the repeat of the main theme very near the end, a short break, and the closing segment. All of the solos are edited out. The single reached #30 on the U.S. Billboard chart. In the Netherlands (and perhaps other territories, too), a different, longer 4-minute, 14-second edit was released first on a 45 with catalogue number 2019 021 and later on an EP with catalogue number 2091 213. This edit features only one verse, a large portion of the drum solo, the final verse, and the closing segment. Another edit, supplied to some radio stations, runs at 5:04. It includes the first verse, about 20 seconds each of the organ and guitar solos, part of the drum solo segueing into the drum/bass solo, the final verse, and the closing of the song.{{citation needed|reason=dubious claim-see Talk page|date=July 2016}} A European compilation album on the EVA label (EMI, Virgin, BMG, Ariola) entitled ''Pop Classics 2'', features a 10:26 edit of "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida". The original soundtrack CD of the movie ''[[Manhunter (film)|Manhunter]]'' features an 8:20 edit of the song. In these edits, mostly the guitar solos were edited out. ===Live version=== A live version over 19 minutes long was released as part of their 1969 live album, simply titled ''[[Live (Iron Butterfly album)|Live]]''. This version lengthens the drum solo by roughly four minutes and the organ solo by about one minute. It also omits the bass and drum solo jam (heard from 13:04–15:19 on the studio recording). When Doug Ingle wrote the song, he had not intended for it to run 17 minutes long. However, Ingle said that he "knew there would be slots for solos". During live renditions, [[Erik Brann]]'s (guitar) and [[Ron Bushy]]'s (drum) solos varied from performance to performance, while Ingle's organ solo remained the same. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Atco Records 7-inch single | title1 = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | note1 = single edit | length1 = 2:52 | title2 = Iron Butterfly Theme | note2 = instrumental | length2 = 3:24 }} {{Track listing | headline = Atlantic Records 7-inch single | title1 = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | note1 = single edit | length1 = 2:52 | title2 = Soul Experience | length2 = 2:50 }} {{Track listing | headline = 1969 French single | title1 = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | note1 = vocal part | length1 = 4:50 | title2 = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | note2 = instrumental featuring drums and organ | length2 = 5:12 }} {{Track listing | headline = 1971 French single | title1 = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | note1 = part 1 | length1 = 3:30 | title2 = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | note2 = part 2 | length2 = 3:58 }} {{Track listing | headline = German single | title1 = In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida | note1 = edit | length1 = 3:10 | title2 = Easy Rider | length2 = 3:06 }} ==Boney M. version== {{unreferenced|section|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox song | name = Children of Paradise" /
"Gadda-Da-Vida | cover = Boney M. - Children Of Paradise (1980 single).jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Boney M.]] | album = | released = September 1980 | format = [[Gramophone record|7-inch single]], [[12-inch single]] | recorded = 1980 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Euro disco]], [[pop music|pop]] | length = | label = [[Hansa Records|Hansa]] (FRG) | writer = [[Doug Ingle]] | producer = [[Frank Farian]] | prev_title = [[I See a Boat on the River / My Friend Jack]] | prev_year = 1980 | title = [[Children of Paradise (Boney M. song)|Children of Paradise]] | title2 = Gadda-Da-Vida | next_title = [[Felicidad (Margherita)]] | next_year = 1980 }} "Children of Paradise" / "Gadda-Da-Vida" is a 1980 single by disco band [[Boney M.]] Intended to be the first single off the group's fifth album ''[[Boonoonoonoos]]'' (scheduled for a November 1980 release), the single was ultimately never included because the album release was delayed for one year. "Children of Paradise" peaked at number 11 in the German charts, whereas it became the group's lowest-placing single in the UK at number 66. Boney M. used the double A-side format in this period, typically with the A1 being the song intended for radio and A2 being more squarely aimed at discos. The sides usually were switched on the accompanying 12" single. "Gadda-Da-Vida" became a controversial Boney M. record since none of the original members sang on it. Because of a fall-out between producer [[Frank Farian]] and the group, he had session singers [[La Mama (band)|La Mama]] ([[Cathy Bartney]], [[Patricia Shockley]], and [[Madeleine Davis]]) sing the female vocals while he did the deep male vocals, as usual. The group only promoted it once on TV. Two different single edits were done of the full 9-minute version that appeared on the 12-inch single. "Gadda-Da-Vida" was the A-side in Japan. Only the French release correctly stated the song title as "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida". ===Releases=== '''7-inch singles''' *"Children of Paradise" (Farian, Reyam, Jay) – 4:40 / "Gadda-Da-Vida" (Ingle) – 5:18 (Hansa 102 400-100, Germany) *"Children of Paradise" (Final mix) – 4:28 / "Gadda-Da-Vida" (Final mix) – 5:05 (Hansa 102 400-100, Germany) '''12-inch single''' *"Gadda-Da-Vida" (Long version) – 8:56 / "Children of Paradise" (12" mix) – 5:18 (Hansa 600 280-100, Germany) ==Other versions== Michael Viner's [[Incredible Bongo Band]] covered the song in 1973. Samples from this version are used in the [[Nas]] songs "[[Thief's Theme]]" and "[[Hip Hop Is Dead (song)|Hip Hop Is Dead]]". The power metal band [[Blind Guardian]] released a remastered version of "Gada-Da-Vida" as a single. The Thrash metal band [[Slayer]] recorded a short and fast version of this song for the movie soundtrack of ''[[Less Than Zero (film)|Less Than Zero]]''. The composer and percussionist [[David Van Tieghem]] released a version and two remixes in 1986.{{cite web |url=http://www.vantieghem.com/discography |title= Discography |website= vantieghem.com |accessdate=April 12, 2018}} Portions of the song are featured in an episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', "[[Bart Sells His Soul]]", in which [[Bart Simpson]] tricks [[Reverend Lovejoy]]'s church into singing the song as an opening hymn by handing out sheet music titled "In the Garden of Eden" by "I. Ron Butterfly". Lovejoy describes the hymn as "sound[ing] like rock and/or roll".{{cite news |last1=Randolph |first1=Laurel |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/08/cooking-the-simpsons-million-dollar-birthday-fries.html |title=Cooking The Simpsons: Million Dollar Birthday Fries |work=[[Paste Magazine]] |date=August 17, 2016 |accessdate=August 26, 2016}} [[Mojo Nixon]] and [[Skid Roper]] recorded the song on their album ''[[Frenzy (Mojo Nixon album)|Frenzy]]''. [[Nash the Slash]] recorded an 8:55 version of the song on his 2008 album ''In-a-Gadda-Da-Nash''. Avant-garde group [[The Residents]] included this song in a medley of other 1960s pop covers on their 1976 album ''[[The Third Reich 'n Roll]]''. [[:de:16 BIT|16 BIT]] (a German dance project from 1986 to 1989 by Michael Münzing and Luca Anzilotti) recorded in 1987 a single "(Ina) Gadda-Da-Vida" https://www.discogs.com/16-Bit-Featuring-Eddie-Hind-Ina-Gadda-Da-Vida/master/84669 https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/16_BIT#Singles, also included in album ''Inaxycvgtgb'' https://www.discogs.com/16-Bit-Inaxycvgtgb/release/23219 New Jersey psychedelic band 6 Feet Under recorded a version in the late 1960s.{{cite web |url=http://psychedelicized.com/playlist/other/6-feet-under/ |title='6 Feet Under' at Psychedelicized.com |accessdate=May 17, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Iron Butterfly}} {{Boney M. singles}} [[Category:1968 singles]] [[Category:Iron Butterfly songs]] [[Category:Mondegreens]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Frank Farian]] [[Category:Boney M. songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Doug Ingle]] [[Category:Atco Records singles]] [[Category:Hansa Records singles]] [[Category:1968 songs]] [[Category:American heavy metal songs]] [[Category:Rock songs]] [[Category:Acid rock songs]]

{{Infobox comic book title <!--Wikipedia:WikiProject Comics--> |title = Insufferable |image = Insufferable promo.jpg |caption = Promotional art by Peter Krause. |schedule = Weekly |ongoing = Y |Superhero = Y |publisher = Thrillbent |startmo = May |startyr = 2012 |endmo = |endyr = |issues = 68 |main_char_team = |writers = [[Mark Waid]] |pencillers = |inkers = |artists = {{ubl|[[Peter Krause (artist)|Peter Krause]]}} |letterers = Troy Peteri |colorists = {{ubl|Nolan Woodard}} |editors = |creators = |TPB = |ISBN = |subcat = |sort = Insufferable }} '''''Insufferable''''' is an [[American comic book]] series written by [[Mark Waid]] and digitally published by Waid's Thrillbent label. The series, described by Waid as a "dramedy", follows an estranged superhero team; the dedicated hero Nocturnus, and his arrogant, egotistical former sidekick Galahad, who are forced to reunite to tackle a new case. ''Insufferable'' reunited Waid with his ''[[Irredeemable]]'' creative team, artist [[Peter Krause (artist)|Peter Krause]] and colorist Nolan Woodward. The series began publication on May 1, 2012, as Thrillbent's launch title.
==Publication history== ''Insufferable'' was first announced on April 14, 2012, at the [[Chicago Comic & Entertainment Expo]] as the first series to be released on Waid's new online digital comic publishing platform ''Thrillbent''.<ref name="CBRApr14">{{cite news |first=Brigid |last=Alverson | url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=38164 |title=C2E2: MARK WAID ANNOUNCES THRILLBENT, "INSUFFERABLE" |work=[[Comic Book Resources]] |publisher=Boiling Point Productions |date=April 14, 2012 |accessdate= April 20, 2012 | archiveurl = | archivedate =| deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="USATodayApr14">{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Truitt | url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/comics/story/2012-04-13/Mark-Waid-Thrillbent-digital-comics-initiative/54265370/1 |title=Mark Waid makes a bold digital move with Thrillbent website |work=[[USA Today]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]] |date=April 14, 2012 |accessdate= April 20, 2012 | archiveurl = | archivedate =| deadurl=no}}</ref>
The first issue of ''Insufferable'' was released on May 1, 2012 on Thrillbent.<ref name="CBRApr14"/><ref name="Release1">{{cite news |first=Todd |last=Alenn | url=http://www.comicsbeat.com/2012/05/01/waids-webcomics-initiative-thrillbent-insufferable-launchs/ |title=Waid’s Webcomics Initiative (Thrillbent / Insufferable) Launches |publisher=[[Comics Beat]] |work= |date=May 1, 2012 |accessdate= May 1, 2012 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120506001250/http://www.comicsbeat.com/2012/05/01/waids-webcomics-initiative-thrillbent-insufferable-launchs| archivedate =6 May 2012| deadurl=yes}}</ref> The comic reunites Waid with his creative team from the finished comic series ''[[Irredeemable]]''; artist [[Peter Krause (artist)|Peter Krause]],<ref name="USATodayApr14"/> colorist Nolan Woodward, and letterer Troy Petrie. Waid designed the comic specifically for digital release as opposed to comics which are designed for print and also released digitally.<ref name="CBRApr14"/> Remarking on the flexibility of digital comics allowing long, short, and one-off series, Waid stated "I can see [''Insufferable''] ending at some point, but I also see how we can do sequels".<ref name="CBRApr14"/>
Unlike traditional print comics, ''Insufferable'' is intended to be released in a 4 x 3 [[Page orientation|landscape]] format to allow pages to fit comfortably on standard horizontal monitors and similar viewing devices. Speaking about the format decision, Waid said "I hate, with a white hot passion, digital comics where I only get to see a little bit of the screen as I go and I have to scroll around to get the sense of what the whole page [is]".<ref name="CBRApr14"/> Waid claimed that releasing the comic digitally was the only option available, as he was not able to afford the cost of releasing it in print, and was selling off his collection of print comics to raise funds for the venture. Additionally he financially partnered with comic writer and television producer John Rogers, and provides his collaborators, like Krause, with co-ownership, trading initially lower rates of payment for potential larger future gains if the series is a success. Waid claimed that if the series was successful and profitable, future releases in print would be possible.<ref name="CBRApr14"/> In October 2013, issues 1-8 were collected in print.<ref>{{cite web|last=Theaker |first=Stephen |url=http://theakersquarterly.blogspot.com/2013/10/insufferable-complete-first-season-by.html |title=Theaker's Quarterly Fiction: Insufferable: The Complete First Season by Mark Waid and Peter Krause, reviewed by Stephen Theaker |publisher=Theakersquarterly.blogspot.com |date=2013-10-14 |accessdate=2016-10-20}}</ref>
Volume 2 finished on November 30, 2013, and the first issue of volume 3 was released on November 12, 2014 after a one-year absence.{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}} Releases have not followed the weekly schedule as was planned, with the 16th issue being released on April 22, 2015.
==Development== In April, Waid described the setting as what happens when a hero has a kid sidekick who grows up to be a "completely ungrateful, self-aggrandizing," "[[Douchebaggery|douchebag]]" who "will not shut up about how much of a genius he is and how the world is a better place now that [the hero team] are broken up because now he can do it all the way he wanted to do it."<ref name="CBRApr14"/> The series follows the events that force the hero and the former sidekick to reunite in spite of their mutual hatred for one another.<ref name="CBRApr14"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Comics|United States|Superhero fiction}} * {{Official website|http://thrillbent.com/}} * [https://twitter.com/thrillbent Official Twitter account] [[Category:Comics by Mark Waid]]

{{Infobox amusement park | name = Italia in miniatura | image = [[File:Italia in miniatura 3.jpg|200px]] | caption = Overview of the park | resort = Late-July 2009 view in [[Viserba]], [[Italy]] | location = | location2 = | location3 = | coordinates = | theme = | homepage = | owner = | general_manager = | operator = | opening_date = {{Start date|df=y|1970|7|4}} | closing_date = | previous_names = | season = | visitors = | area = | rides = | coasters = | water_rides = | slogan = | status = | footnotes = }} '''Italia in Miniatura''' is a leisure and [[miniature park]] in Viserba, a part of [[Rimini]] ([[Italy]]).
The park displays 273 miniatures of famous Italian and European buildings in scale 1:25 and 1:50. The area is surrounded by ''Arcobaleno'' (Italian: rainbow), a monorail. 10,000 plants and 5,000 miniature trees are integrated in the landscape. To fill the water basins 2,500 m<sup>3</sup> of water are needed. 17 miniature trains are running in the system.
On an area of 12,000 m<sup>2</sup> there is a replica of the [[Grand Canal (Venice)|Grand Canal]] of [[Venice]] with reproductions of 119 buildings in scale of 1:5. The campanile on [[Piazza San Marco|St. Mark's Square]] has a height of 20 metres.
In ''Cannonacqua'', a replica of the [[Castel Sismondo]] in Rimini, medieval battles between the noble families of [[House of Montefeltro|Montefeltro]] and [[House of Malatesta|Malatesta]] with water cannons can be replayed.
There are also the log flume ''Canoe'', the parrot park ''Pappamondo'', as well as the ''Luna Park della scienza'' with physical experiments for children. Since 2011 the project ''YouMini'' miniaturizes parc visitors in scale 1:33.
The park opens daily from March to September. it is situated right at the Strada Statale Adriatica 16 about 5 km north of the centre of Rimini.

Monique Delacroix (Mother) | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] }} [[Commander (Royal Navy)|Commander]] [[James Bond]] [[Royal Navy|RN]]—code number 007—is a fictional character created by the British journalist and novelist [[Ian Fleming]] in 1952. The [[James Bond (literary character)|character]] appeared in a series of [[List of James Bond novels and short stories|twelve novels and two short story collections]] written by Fleming and a number of continuation novels and spin-off works after Fleming's death in 1964. There have been [[James Bond in film|twenty-six films]] in total, produced between 1962 and 2015. Fleming portrayed Bond as a tall, athletic, handsome secret agent in his thirties or forties; he has several vices including drinking, smoking, gambling, automobiles and womanising. He is an exceptional marksman, and skilled in unarmed combat, skiing, swimming and golf. While Bond kills without hesitation or regret, he usually kills only when carrying out orders, while acting in self-defence and occasionally as revenge. American actor [[Barry Nelson]] was the first to portray Bond on screen, in a 1954 television adaptation, "[[Casino Royale (Climax!)|Casino Royale]]". In 1961 [[Eon Productions]] began work on [[Dr. No (film)|''Dr. No'']], an adaptation of the [[Dr. No (novel)|novel of the same name]]. The result was a film that spawned a series of twenty-four films produced by [[Eon Productions]] and two independent films. After considering the likes of "refined" English actors such as [[Cary Grant]] and [[David Niven]], the producers cast [[Sean Connery]] as Bond in the film. Fleming was appalled at the selection of the uncouth, 31-year-old Scottish actor, considering him to be the antithesis of his character. However, Connery's physical prowess and sexual magnetism in the role came to be closely identified with the character, with Fleming ultimately changing his view on Connery and incorporating aspects of his portrayal into the books. Seven actors in total have portrayed Bond on film. Following Connery's portrayal, [[David Niven]], [[George Lazenby]], [[Roger Moore]], [[Timothy Dalton]], [[Pierce Brosnan]] and [[Daniel Craig]] have assumed the role. These screen versions have retained many traits from Fleming's depiction, although some of Bond's less fashionable attitudes have been dropped, such as [[racism]], [[homophobia]], retaining the services of a maid, and in the more recent films, smoking. Despite playing the same character, there have been notable differences among the portrayals. Daniel Craig is the incumbent Bond in the long-running Eon series, and played the part for a fourth time in the latest film, ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]'', released in October 2015. ==Fleming's literary characterisation== {{See also|James Bond (literary character)}} A [[Secret Intelligence Service|Secret Service]] agent, James Bond was a composite based on a number of [[commando]]s whom author [[Ian Fleming]] had known during his service in the [[Naval Intelligence Division]] during [[World War II]], to whom he added his own style and a number of his own tastes. Fleming appropriated his character's name from the [[James Bond (ornithologist)|eponymous American ornithologist]]. Bond's code number 007 comes from one of British naval intelligence's key achievements of [[World War I]]: the breaking of the German diplomatic code.{{sfn|Macintyre|2008|p=65}} One of the German documents cracked and read by the British was the [[Zimmermann Telegram]], which was coded 0075,{{sfn|Chancellor|2005|p=190}} and which was one of the factors that led the US entering the war. Subsequently, if material was graded 00 it meant it was highly classified. Fleming later told a journalist: "When I was at the Admiralty ... all the top-secret signals had the double-0 prefix ... and I decided to borrow it for Bond."{{sfn|Macintyre|2008|p=65}} Although James Bond is in his mid-to-late thirties, he does not age in Fleming's stories.{{sfn|Black|2005|p=176}} Fleming biographer [[Andrew Lycett]] noted that, "within the first few pages [of [[Casino Royale (novel)|''Casino Royale'']]] Ian had introduced most of Bond's idiosyncrasies and trademarks", which included his looks, his Bentley and his smoking and drinking habits:{{sfn|Lycett|1996|p=257}} Bond's penchant for alcohol runs throughout the series of books{{sfn|Chancellor|2005|p=90}} and he smokes up to 70 cigarettes a day.{{sfn|Cabrera Infante|1985|p=212}}{{efn|The cigarettes Bond smoked were the same as Fleming's, who had been buying his at Morland of Grosvenor Street since the 1930s; the three gold bands on the filter were added during the war to mirror his naval Commander's rank.{{sfn|Chancellor|2005|p=70}} Fleming himself smoked up to 80 cigarettes a day.}} Fleming decided to underplay Bond's character, observing: "Exotic things would happen to and around him, but he would be a neutral figure." On another occasion, he reinforced his point: "When I wrote the first one in 1953, I wanted Bond to be an extremely dull, uninteresting man to whom things happened; I wanted him to be a blunt instrument." ==Films== {{Gallery |title=Timeline of Eon-produced James Bond films |align=right |footer={{James Bond Timeline}} }} ===Sean Connery: 1962–1967, 1971 and 1983=== [[Sean Connery]] was the first actor to portray Bond on film in ''[[Dr. No (film)|Dr. No]]'' (1962). An amateur bodybuilder, he had come to the attention of the Bond film producers after several appearances in British films from the late 1950s. At a muscular 6'2", Connery was initially met with disapproval from Fleming, who believed him to be an overgrown stuntman who lacked the finesse and elegance to play James Bond; he envisaged a suave actor, such as [[David Niven]] playing the role.{{sfn|Black|2005|p=113}} Producer [[Albert R. Broccoli]]—known to all as Cubby—disagreed with Fleming's view, later commenting that "I wanted a ballsy guy ... put a bit of veneer over that tough Scottish hide and you've got Fleming's Bond instead of all the mincing poofs we had applying for the job".{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|pp=9–10}} Eon's choice of Connery was also based on his looks and sex appeal,{{sfn|Broccoli|1998|p=166}} an appeal that would later be echoed by [[Honor Blackman]] who said, after appearing with Connery in ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'', "He was exceedingly handsome, virile and sexy and that really was the tenor of what the script was always trying to display".{{sfn|Parker|1993|p=112}} After Connery was chosen, director [[Terence Young (director)|Terence Young]] took the actor to his tailor and hairdresser, and introduced him to the high life, restaurants, casinos and women of London. In the words of Bond writer [[Raymond Benson]], Young educated the actor "in the ways of being dapper, witty, and above all, cool".{{Cite journal|last=Benson|first=Raymond|author-link=Raymond Benson|title=Can the Cinematic Bond Ever Be the Literary Bond? |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=zpI5RbRwnd4C&pg=PA7 7]|ref=harv}} In {{harvnb|Yeffeth|2006}}. Connery's interpretation of the character differed considerably from Fleming's, being more promiscuous and cold blooded than the literary version.{{sfn|Macintyre|2008|p=204}} Connery described Bond as "a complete sensualist—senses highly tuned, awake to everything, quite amoral. I particularly like him because he thrives on conflict". Academic [[James Chapman (media historian)|James Chapman]] observed that for ''Dr. No'', Connery's interpretation of the character, although not complete, showed the actor "should be credited with having established a new style of performance: a British screen hero in the manner of an American leading man".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=64}} In his second film, [[From Russia with Love (film)|''From Russia with Love'']], Connery looked less nervous and edgy; he gave "a relaxed, wry performance of subtle wit and style".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=76}} Pfeiffer and Worrall noted that Connery "personified James Bond with such perfection that even Ian Fleming ... admitted that it was difficult imagining anyone else in the part";{{sfn|Pfeiffer|Worrall|1998|p=13}}{{efn|Fleming later adapted the background of the [[James Bond (literary character)|literary character]] in [[You Only Live Twice (novel)|''You Only Live Twice'']] to have a Scottish heritage,{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=164}}{{sfn|Chancellor|2005|p=75}} although Fleming himself was part Scottish. Correspondence dating back to 1960 shows that Fleming contacted a Scottish nobleman to help research Bond's family history, in particular seeking a Scottish Bond line.{{sfn|Helfenstein|2009}} }} academic [[Jeremy Black (historian)|Jeremy Black]] agreed and declared that "Connery made the role his own and created the Bond audience for the cinema".{{sfn|Black|2005|p=114}} Black also observed that Connery gave the character a "spare, pared-down character ... [with] inner bleakness along with the style".{{sfn|Black|2005|p=114}} Connery played Bond with "the right mix of cool charisma, violence and arrogance ... against which all others are judged".{{sfn|Simpson|2002|p=134}} Raymond Benson perceived that Connery "embodies a ruggedness and an intense screen presence this transcends any preconceived notions about the character".{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=170}} Benson also noted that Bond was witty, but contains "an assured toughness that epitomises the machismo male".{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=170}} [[Roger Moore]] agreed with Black and Benson, commenting that "Sean ''was'' Bond. He created Bond. He embodied Bond and because of Sean, Bond became an instantly recognisable character the world over—he was rough, tough, mean and witty ... he was a bloody good 007".{{sfn|Moore|2012|p=152}} However, despite his charm and virility, Connery was characteristically laconic in his delivery.{{cite book|author=Princeton Institute for Historic Research|title=Automobile Quarterly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AlZWAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=28 September 2012|year=2002|publisher=Automobile Quarterly|page=18}}{{cite book|author=American Chamber of Commerce (United Kingdom)|title=Atlantic|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cpkXAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=28 September 2012|year=1989|publisher=American Chamber of Commerce (United Kingdom)|page=12}} Christopher Bray says of him that "in his single-minded, laconic, mocking, self-sufficient vanity, Connery's Bond was the epitome of sixties consumer culture".{{sfn|Bray|2010|p=155}} [[File:Sean Connery 1971.jpg|thumb|left|Connery in [[Amsterdam]] in July 1971, filming ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]''.]] Interviewed by [[Oriana Fallaci]] in 1965, Connery identified where he had altered the character for the films, saying "I said to the producers that the character had one defect, there was no humor about him; to get him accepted, they'd have to let me play him tongue-in-cheek, so people could laugh. They agreed, and there you are: today Bond is accepted to such an extent that even philosophers take the trouble to analyze him, even intellectuals enjoy defending him or attacking him. And even while they're laughing at him, people take him terribly seriously".{{sfn|Fallaci|1968|p=29}} Connery went on to add that "Bond is important: this invincible superman that every man would like to copy, that every woman would like to conquer, this dream we all have of survival. And then one can't help liking him".{{sfn|Fallaci|1968|p=29}} After the pressures of five films in six years, Connery left the role after the 1967 film ''[[You Only Live Twice (film)|You Only Live Twice]]'' saying, "It became a terrible pressure, like living in a goldfish bowl ... that was part of the reason I wanted to be finished with Bond. Also I had become completely identified with it, and it became very wearing and very boring".{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=78}} After a hiatus of one film—[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service (film)|''On Her Majesty's Secret Service'']], in which [[George Lazenby]] played Bond—Connery returned to the role for ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]'' after David Picker, the head of [[United Artists]], made it clear that Connery was to be enticed back to the role and that money was no object. When approached about resuming the role of Bond, Connery demanded—and received—a fee of £1.25 million (£{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|1.25|1962}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|UK}} pounds),{{inflation-fn|UK}} 12.5% of the gross profits{{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|p=429}} and, as a further enticement, United Artists offered to back two films of his choice.{{sfn|Feeney Callan|2002|p=217}}{{efn|After both sides agreed to the deal, Connery used the fee to establish the Scottish International Education Trust, where Scottish artists could apply for funding without having to leave their country to pursue their careers. Since John Gavin, who had been signed to play Bond, was no longer required, Broccoli insisted that he be paid in full. The first film made under Connery's deal was ''[[The Offence]]'' directed by his friend [[Sidney Lumet]]. The second was to be an adaptation of ''[[Macbeth]]'' by [[William Shakespeare]] using only Scottish actors and in which Connery himself would play the title role. This project was abandoned because another production of ''Macbeth'' (the [[Roman Polanski]] version) was already in production.}} His performance received mixed reviews, with Raymond Benson considering that Connery "looks weary and bored ... he is overweight, slow-moving, and doesn't seem to be trying to create a credible character".{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=192}} Despite that, Benson considers that Connery "still radiates more screen presence than Roger Moore or George Lazenby".{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=192}} On the other hand, [[Pauline Kael]] said "Connery's James Bond is less lecherous than before and less foppish—and he's better this way".{{sfn|Kael|1985|p=189}} In the early 1980s producer [[Jack Schwartzman]] moved ahead with a non-Eon Bond film, following the controversy over the 1961 novel [[Thunderball (novel)|''Thunderball'']]{{sfn|Pfeiffer|Worrall|1998|p=213}} and the subsequent [[Thunderball (novel)#Controversy|long legal battle]]; the result was ''[[Never Say Never Again]]''. Connery accepted an offer to play Bond once more, asking for (and receiving) a fee of $3 million (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|3|1983}}}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars),{{inflation-fn|US|df=y}} a percentage of the profits, as well as casting, director and script approval.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=154}} The script has several references to Bond's advancing years—playing on Connery being 52 at the time of filming.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=154}}{{sfn|Black|2005|p=58}} [[David Robinson (film critic)|David Robinson]], reviewing the film for ''[[The Times]]'' considered that, "Connery ... is back, looking hardly a day older or thicker, and still outclassing every other exponent of the role, in the goodnatured throwaway with which he parries all the sex and violence on the way". In 2003 Bond, as portrayed by Connery, was selected as the [[AFI's 100 Years... 100 Heroes and Villains|third-greatest hero in cinema history]] by the [[American Film Institute]].{{cite web|title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes & Villains|url=http://www.afi.com/100Years/handv.aspx|work=[[AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes & Villains]]|publisher=[[American Film Institute]]|accessdate=20 December 2013}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ Sean Connery as James Bond in: |- ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:55px;" | Year ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:225px;" | Film ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top;" | Salary $ (millions){{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|pp=428–429}} |- ! scope="row" | 1962 | ''[[Dr. No (film)|Dr. No]]'' | 0.1{{efn|Balio sets Connery's compensation for ''Dr. No'' at $154,000: $54,000 as salary and $100,000 as a bonus.{{sfn|Balio|1987|p=260}}}} |- ! scope="row" | 1963 | ''[[From Russia with Love (film)|From Russia with Love]]'' | 0.3 |- ! scope="row" | 1964 | ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' | 0.5 |- ! scope="row" | 1965 | ''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' | 0.8 |- ! scope="row" | 1967 | ''[[You Only Live Twice (film)|You Only Live Twice]]'' | 0.8 + 25% net merchandise royalty |- ! scope="row" | 1971 | ''[[Diamonds Are Forever (film)|Diamonds Are Forever]]'' | 1.2 + 12.5% of gross{{efn|Balio claims Connery was paid a straight 12.5% of the gross. ''Diamonds Are Forever'' grossed $42 million so Connery received over $5 million from which he gave $1.25 million to the Scottish International Education Trust.{{sfn|Balio|1987|p=264}}}} |- ! scope="row" | 1983 | ''[[Never Say Never Again]]'' (Non-Eon film) | 3.0 + unknown % of profits{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=154}} |} ===David Niven: 1967=== [[File:David niven in casino royal.jpg|thumb|[[David Niven]] starred in the 1967 film ''[[Casino Royale (1967 film)|Casino Royale]]'']] When Sean Connery had been cast in November 1961,{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=9}} [[David Niven]] had been Fleming's choice for the role as the actor reflected his image of the character.{{sfn|Black|2005|p=113}} In 1965 producer [[Charles Feldman]] signed Niven to play Sir James Bond for ''[[Casino Royale (1967 film)|Casino Royale]]'', a film not made by [[Eon Productions]]. Connery and [[Peter Sellers]] had both turned down the role.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=57}}{{sfn|Walker|1981|p=136}} Niven was 56 when he played Bond{{sfn|Ash|2007|p=149}} and his characterisation was that of an elderly man who had won the [[Victoria Cross]] at the [[Siege of Mafeking]], had a daughter by his lover, the spy [[Mata Hari]], played [[Claude Debussy]] on the piano, ate [[royal jelly]] and cultivated black roses.{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=70}}{{sfn|Rubin|2003|p=44}} The concept of Bond is that once Niven's Bond retired, his name and 007 designation was passed to another agent to keep the legend alive; James Chapman notes that the implication was that the "other Bond" was that played by Connery.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=107}} Chapman considered the concept of an elderly Bond to be an interesting one, with Bond referring to Connery's Bond as a "sexual acrobat who leaves a trail of beautiful dead women behind like blown roses".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=107}} In line with the literary Bond, Niven's character drives a [[Bentley 4½ Litre|vintage Bentley]], rather than the [[Aston Martin]] favoured by Connery.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=107}} Bond scholar Steven Jay Rubin thought Niven perfectly cast as the retired Bond, and saw him as "a throw-back to the hell-for-leather adventure heroes" of the character, which paralleled Niven's own life and career.{{sfn|Rubin|2003|p=308}} Barnes and Hearn describe this as a "perfectly fair interpretation", given the way Niven approached the role,{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=70}} while Raymond Benson thinks casting Niven was "intelligent".{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=239}} Jeremy Black questioned the use of Niven in the role, observing that he did not seem to be a killer, and did not have the "disconcerting edge" that Connery had.{{sfn|Black|2005|p=113}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ David Niven as James Bond in: |- ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:55px;" | Year ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:225px;" | Film ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top;" | Salary $ (millions){{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|pp=428–429}} |- ! scope="row" | 1967 | ''[[Casino Royale (1967 film)|Casino Royale]]'' (Non-Eon film) | Unknown |} ===George Lazenby: 1969=== [[File:GeorgeLazenby11.14.08ByLuigiNovi.jpg|thumb|left|[[George Lazenby]] at the November 2008 [[Big Apple Con]] in [[Manhattan]]|alt=Grey haired man in red check shirt, sitting at a table on which his hands are resting.]] With the departure of Connery after ''You Only Live Twice'', Broccoli and director [[Peter R. Hunt]] chose Australian [[George Lazenby]] to play the role of Bond. He first came to their attention after seeing him in a [[Fry's Chocolate Cream]] advertisement. Lazenby dressed the part by sporting several sartorial Bond elements such as a [[Rolex]] Submariner wristwatch and a [[Savile Row tailoring|Savile Row]] suit (ordered, but uncollected, by Connery), and going to Connery's barber at the [[Dorchester Hotel]]. Lazenby consolidated his claim during a screen test, when he accidentally punched a [[professional wrestler]], who was acting as [[stunt coordinator]], in the face, impressing Broccoli with his ability to display aggression.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=82}} Lazenby never signed a contract, with negotiations dragging on during production,{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=86}} and he was subsequently convinced by his agent [[Ronan O'Rahilly]] that the secret agent would be archaic in the liberated 1970s; as a result he left the role before the release of ''On Her Majesty's Secret Service'' in 1969. For his performance as Bond, Lazenby was nominated for the [[Golden Globe Award for New Star of the Year – Actor]] at the [[27th Golden Globe Awards]]. Critical opinion was split about Lazenby; he has been considered to have been the worst Bond,{{sfn|Bishop|2011|p=38}} and has variously been described as "laconic and humourless",{{sfn|Macintyre|2008|p=204}} "a little stiff"{{sfn|Pratt|2005|p=882}} and "annoying and smug". [[Derek Malcolm]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' was dismissive of Lazenby's performance, saying that he "is not a good actor and though I never thought Sean Connery was all that stylish either, there are moments when one yearns for a little of his louche panache". ''[[The New York Times]]'' critic AH Weiler also weighed in against Lazenby, saying that "Lazenby, if not a spurious Bond, is merely a casual, pleasant, satisfactory replacement". Pauline Kael called Lazenby "quite a dull fellow" in her otherwise positive review in ''[[The New Yorker]]''.{{sfn|Kael|1985|p=}} However, [[Peter R. Hunt]], director of ''On Her Majesty's Secret Service'', stated that Lazenby should have undertaken more films in the role, saying "he would have made a very credible Bond and been very good indeed".{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=27}} Smith and Lavington consider that Lazenby "had chosen to play Bond the same way as Sean Connery had, with perhaps more humility and humanity";{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=117}} they went on to say that "Lazenby's inexperience rarely shows" in the film, and that "he invariably rises to the occasion".{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=102}} [[Alexander Walker (critic)|Alexander Walker]] in the ''London [[Evening Standard]]'' said that, "The truth is that George Lazenby is almost as good a James Bond as the man referred to in his film as 'the other fellow'. Lazenby's voice is more suave than sexy-sinister and he could pass for the other fellow's twin on the shady side of the casino. Bond is now definitely all set for the Seventies". Judith Crist of ''[[New York Magazine]]'' commented that, "This time around there's less suavity and a no-nonsense muscularity and maleness to the role via the handsome Mr. Lazenby". Feminist film critic [[Molly Haskell]] wrote an approving review in the ''[[Village Voice]]'': "Lazenby ... seems more comfortable in a wet tuxedo than a dry martini, more at ease as a donnish genealogist than reading (or playing) ''[[Playboy]]'', and who actually dares to think that one woman who is his equal is better than a thousand part-time playmates". James Chapman considers that Lazenby looks the part of Bond, identifying his athleticism and "arrogant swagger", which "convey the snobbery of the character".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=115}} Chapman also distinguished a more vulnerable and human characterisation in Bond—feeling exhausted and falling in love—as opposed to the "heroic superman" of Connery.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=115}} Brian Fairbanks noted that "''OHMSS'' gives us a James Bond capable of vulnerability, a man who can show fear and is not immune to heartbreak. Lazenby is that man, and his performance is superb".{{sfn|Fairbanks|2005|p=258}} Ben Macintyre also observed that of all the Bonds, Lazenby's characterisation was closest to that of Fleming's original character.{{sfn|Macintyre|2008|p=204}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ George Lazenby as James Bond in: |- ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:55px;" | Year ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:225px;" | Film ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top;" | Salary $ (millions){{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|pp=428–429}} |- ! scope="row" | 1969 | ''[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service (film)|On Her Majesty's Secret Service]]'' | 0.1 |} ===Roger Moore: 1972–1985=== [[File:Sir Roger Moore Allan Warren.jpg|thumb|[[Roger Moore]] in 1973, photographed by [[Allan Warren]].]] After ''Diamonds Are Forever'', Broccoli and Saltzman tried to convince Sean Connery to return as Bond, but he declined. After considering [[Jeremy Brett]], [[Michael Billington (actor)|Michael Billington]] and [[Julian Glover]],{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=137}}{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=105}} the two producers finally turned to [[Roger Moore]], who they had previously discussed for ''[[On Her Majesty's Secret Service (film)|On Her Majesty's Secret Service]]'', but who had been unavailable, and he was ultimately cast to play Bond in [[Live and Let Die (film)|''Live and Let Die'']].{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=82}} At the time Moore was an established television actor, known for his performances as [[Simon Templar]] in ''[[The Saint (TV series)|The Saint]]'' and Lord Brett Sinclair in ''[[The Persuaders!]]'': in both of which he played a "charming, debonair, international playboy".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=124}} When playing Bond, Moore tried not to imitate either Connery or his previous roles, and screenwriter [[Tom Mankiewicz]] fitted the screenplay around Moore's persona by giving more comedy scenes and a light-hearted feel to Bond, an approach that led Raymond Benson to describe Moore's Bond as "a rather smarmy, eyebrow-raising international playboy who never seemed to get hurt".{{sfn|Yeffeth|2006|p=9}} Film writer Andrew Spicer considered Roger Moore to be the most elegant and mannerly of the Bonds, with the voice and style of an English debonair country gentleman.{{sfn|Spicer|2003|p=185}} Benson agreed, stating that Moore was, "too nice and well-mannered to be a James Bond of any real substance",{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=164}} while Doug Pratt said that "the writers worked out an amenable personality for Roger Moore and found a breezy balance between comedy and action".{{sfn|Pratt|2005|p=1140}} To make Moore's character appear tougher, a [[Smith & Wesson Model 29|Smith & Wesson .44 Magnum]] — which at the time was associated with the macho image of the [[Clint Eastwood]] character, [[Harry Callahan (character)|Dirty Harry]] — was chosen for Moore to use in ''Live and Let Die'' rather than Bond's usual choice of [[Walther PP|Walther PPK]].{{sfn|Spicer|2003|p=129}} Spicer says "Roger Moore re-created Bond as an old-style debonair hero, more polished and sophisticated than Connery's incarnation, using the mocking insouciance he had perfected in his role as [[Simon Templar]] ... Moore's humour was a throwaway, and certainly in the later films, verged on self-parody. It was an essential strand in the increasingly tongue-in-cheek direction of the series which became more light-hearted, knowing and playfully intertextual".{{sfn|Spicer|2003|p=185}} Chapman noted that Moore was the most comedic of the Bonds, with a more light-hearted approach to playing the character with a mocking wit and innuendo.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=124}} Additionally, Moore's [[One-line joke|one-liners]] were delivered in a way to suggest that the violence inherent in the films was a joke, as opposed to Connery's, which was used to mitigate the violence.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|pp=124–125}} Moore explained his approach to the humour by saying "to me, the Bond situations are so ridiculous ... I mean, this man is supposed to be a spy, and yet everybody knows he's a spy ... it's outrageous. So you have to treat the humour outrageously as well".{{sfn|Life Magazine|2012|p=61}} Pauline Kael was a fairly vocal critic of Moore's, dismissing him as an "iceberg" in ''[[The Man with the Golden Gun (film)|The Man with the Golden Gun]]''. In reviewing ''[[For Your Eyes Only (film)|For Your Eyes Only]]'', she wrote "Roger Moore is Bond again, and his idea of Bond's imperturbable cool is the same as playing dead". Reviewing ''[[Moonraker (film)|Moonraker]]'', she wrote "Roger Moore is dutiful and passive as Bond; his clothes are neatly pressed and he shows up for work, like an office manager who is turning into dead wood but hanging on to collect his pension". Only in ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]'', one of Kael's favourite Bond films, did she praise him describing him as self-effacing: "Moore gets the chance to look scared{{mdash}}an emotion that suits him and makes him more likable".{{sfn|Kael|1985|p=}} A number of Moore's personal preferences were transferred into his characterisation of Bond: his taste for Cuban cigars and his wearing of safari suits were assigned to the character.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=125}} Moore's use for cigars in his early films put him in contrast to the cigarette-smoking Connery, Lazenby and Dalton.{{sfn|Life Magazine|2012|p=118}} By the time of Moore's fifth film, ''[[For Your Eyes Only (film)|For Your Eyes Only]]'', released in 1981, his characterisation had come to represent an old-fashioned character, in contrast to the fashionability Connery had brought to the role in the 1960s.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|pp=170–171}} In 1985 Moore appeared in his seventh and final film, ''[[A View to a Kill]]''; he was 57 (he appeared alongside co-star [[Tanya Roberts]], who was 30).{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=206}} Critics focused on Moore's age:{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=194}} ''[[The Washington Post]]'' said "Moore isn't just long in the tooth – he's got tusks, and what looks like an eye job has given him the pie-eyed blankness of a zombie. He's not believable anymore in the action sequences, even less so in the romantic scenes". When he was cast for the film, Moore recalled that he felt "a bit long in the tooth",{{sfn|Moore|2008|p=255}} and in December 2007 admitted that he "was only about four hundred years too old for the part". Like Connery, Moore appeared as Bond in seven films; by the time he retired in 1985, he was the oldest actor to play 007 in the Eon series,{{sfn|Life Magazine|2012|p=55}} and his Bond films had earned over {{nowrap|$1 billion}} at the box office.{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=29}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ Roger Moore as James Bond in: |- ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:55px;" | Year ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:225px;" | Film ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top;" | Salary $ (millions){{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|pp=428–429}}{{sfn|Balio|1987|p=266}} |- ! scope="row" | 1973 | ''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'' |0.18{{sfn|Balio|1987|p=266}} |- ! scope="row" | 1974 | ''{{sort|man|[[The Man with the Golden Gun (film)|The Man with the Golden Gun]]}}'' |0.24 + 2.5%{{sfn|Balio|1987|p=266}} |- ! scope="row" | 1977 | ''{{sort|spy|[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]}}'' |0.3 + 3.75%{{sfn|Balio|1987|p=266}} |- ! scope="row" | 1979 | ''[[Moonraker (film)|Moonraker]]'' |Unknown |- ! scope="row" | 1981 | ''[[For Your Eyes Only (film)|For Your Eyes Only]]'' |Unknown |- ! scope="row" | 1983 | ''[[Octopussy]]'' | 4.0 |- ! scope="row" | 1985 | ''{{sort|view|[[A View to a Kill]]}}'' | 5.0 |} ===Timothy Dalton: 1986–1994=== With the retirement of Roger Moore in 1985, a search for a new actor to play Bond took place that saw a number of actors, including [[Sam Neill]], [[Pierce Brosnan]]{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=168}} and [[Timothy Dalton]], audition for the role in 1986. Bond co-producer [[Michael G. Wilson]], director John Glen, Dana and Barbara Broccoli "were impressed with Sam Neill and very much wanted to use him", although Bond producer Albert R. Broccoli was not sold on the actor.{{sfn|Broccoli|1998|p=281}} Dalton and Brosnan were both considered by Eon,{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=30}}{{sfn|Paterson|2012|p=64}} but after Brosnan was eventually ruled out by his [[Remington Steele]] contract,{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=168}} Dalton was appointed in August 1986{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=170}} on a salary of $5.2 million.{{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|p=429}} When he was either 24 or 25 years old Dalton had discussed playing Bond with Broccoli, but decided he was too young to accept the role, thinking Bond should be played between 35 and 40 years old.{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=30}} In preparing for the role, Dalton, a green-eyed, dark haired, slender, 6'2" (1 m 88 cm) classically trained [[Shakespeare]]an actor,{{sfn|Paterson|2012|p=59}} was keen to portray the character as accurately as possible, reading up extensively on the books before his role in ''[[The Living Daylights]]'' (1987). {{sfn|Rubin|2003|pp=98–99}} [[File:Timothy Dalton 1987.jpg|thumb|190px|left|[[Timothy Dalton]] played Bond twice, in 1987 and 1989]] Dalton's Bond was a serious one: dark, cold, emotional, stern, ruthless, showing little humour, and focused as a killer with little time for fun and indulgence.{{sfn|Macintyre|2008|p=204}}{{sfn|Simpson|2002|p=141}} Dalton's interpretation of the character came from his "desire to see a darker Bond",{{sfn|Moore|2012|p=160}} one that was "less of a womaniser, tougher and closer to the darker character Ian Fleming wrote about".{{sfn|Moore|2012|p=160}} James Chapman also considered Dalton to be closer to Fleming's Bond than the previous actors, writing that Dalton was "clearly less comfortable ... with the witty asides and one-liners ... so he becomes something closer to the Bond of the books, who rarely develops a sense of humour".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=198}} When reviewing ''Licence to Kill'', Iain Johnstone of ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' disagreed, declaring that "any vestiges of the gentleman spy ... by Ian Fleming" have now gone; he went on to say that "this character is remarkably close both in deed and action to the [[Batman|eponymous hero]] of the new [[Batman (1989 film)|''Batman'']] film". Not all viewers were taken with Dalton. [[Jay Scott]] of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' was entirely dismissive. "The new Bond has been widely described in feature stories as a throwback to the Ian Fleming original (studying the Fleming novels, Dalton was pleased to discover that Bond was a human being, he says), and that may be true, if the Fleming original lacked charm, sex appeal and wit. Timothy Dalton's Bond is a serious bloke who swallows his words and approaches his job with responsibility and humanity, and eschews promiscuity – [[Harry Callahan (character)|Dirtless Harry]]. You get the feeling that on his off nights, he might curl up with the [[Reader's Digest]] and catch an episode of [[Moonlighting (TV series)|Moonlighting]] – he'd try to memorize the jokes – before nodding off under the influence of Ovaltine. The British reviews of ''The Living Daylights'' have been laudatory, perhaps because this Bond is the most British of all, if British is to be understood as a synonym for reserved". Raymond Benson noted that Dalton "purposely played Bond as a ruthless and serious man with very little of the wit displayed by Connery, Lazenby or Moore",{{sfn|Yeffeth|2006|p=10}} and considered him to be "the most accurate and literal interpretation of the role ... ever seen on screen".{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=259}} His character also reflected a degree of moral ambiguity; in ''Licence to Kill'', for instance, he becomes a rogue agent,{{sfn|Spicer|2003|p=185}} while Dalton himself saw the character as a "man, not a superhuman; a man who is beset with moral confusions and apathies and uncertainties, and who is often very frightened and nervous and tense".{{sfn|Benson|1988|p=259}} Smith and Lavington observed that during Dalton's portrayal in ''[[Licence to Kill]]'', Bond appeared "self-absorbed ... reckless, brutal, prone to nervous laughter and ... probably insane, or at least seriously disturbed.{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=225}} In the light of ''Licence to Kill'', one academic, Martin Willis, referred to Dalton's Bond as a "muscular vigilante".{{sfn|Lindner|2009|p=169}} Steven Jay Rubin noted that Dalton's films had "a hard-edged reality and some unflinching violent episodes that were better suited to Dalton's more realistic approach to the character".{{sfn|Rubin|2003|p=97}} Rubin considered Dalton's portrayal to be "Fleming's Bond ... the suffering Bond".{{sfn|Rubin|2003|p=99}} In contrast to the previous incarnations of the character, Smith and Lavington identified Dalton's humour as "brooding rather than flippant";{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=213}} combined with his heavy smoking, they considered him "an effective leading man".{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=213}} Eoghan Lyng, writing for The James Bond Dossier, favourably compared him to [[Daniel Craig]], stating that "Despite chronological placement, it was Dalton, not Brosnan, who proved to be the prototype for the 21st century Bond.".{{cite web|url=http://www.thejamesbonddossier.com/content/timothy-dalton-the-problem-eliminator.htm|title=Timothy Dalton: The Problem Eliminator|website=The James Bond Dossier|last=Lyng |first=Eoghan|date=21 April 2015}} Although Bond screenwriter Richard Maibaum called [[Sean Connery]] the best Bond, he considered Dalton the best actor of the four he worked with.{{cite web|first=Aljean |last=Harmetz |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/09/movies/film-creating-a-thriller-their-words-are-their-bond.html| title=Creating a Thriller, Their Words Are Their Bond| date=9 July 1989| work=The New York Times}} His predecessor, Roger Moore also felt that Dalton was the best actor to play Bond.{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Tim|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3288147/Bond-row-looms-Roger-Moore-says-007-t-gay-woman-Star-88-says-political-correctness-not-considered.html|title=Bond row looms as Roger Moore says 007 can't be gay - or a woman|date= 25 October 2015|work=Daily Mail}} Director John Glen also felt that Dalton was the best actor that portrayed Bond, and that he was ahead of his time, noting the comparisons between Daniel Craig's incarnation to that of Dalton's.|James Bond Radio|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fsIwjzHsESU Dalton's films did not perform as well at the box office as most of the previous films. Commentators such as ''[[Screen International]]'' considered the Bond series had run its course in the age of series such as [[Indiana Jones]] and ''Lethal Weapon''.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=211}} Edward P. Comentale observed that "Dalton, for all his occasional flat northern vowels, was probably too much the stage actor to be convincing as an action hero in the age of [[Bruce Willis|Willis]], [[Arnold Schwarzenegger|Schwarzenegger]] and [[Sylvester Stallone|Stallone]]".{{sfn|Comentale|Watt|Willman|2005|p=139}} After just two films—''The Living Daylights'' and ''Licence to Kill''—litigation ensued over the licensing of the Bond catalogue, delaying what would have been Dalton's third film by several years. His six-year contract expired in 1993 and he left the series in 1994.{{sfn|Moore|2012|pp=161–2}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ Timothy Dalton as James Bond in: |- ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:55px;" | Year ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:225px;" | Film ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top;" | Salary $ (millions){{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|pp=428–429}} |- ! scope="row" | 1987 | ''{{sort|living|[[The Living Daylights]]}}'' | 3.0 |- ! scope="row" | 1989 | ''[[Licence to Kill]]'' | 5.0 |} ===Pierce Brosnan: 1994–2004=== [[File:PierceBrosnanCannesPhoto2.jpg|thumb|left|[[Pierce Brosnan]] at the [[2002 Cannes Film Festival]]|alt=Smiling man with short, tousled hair, wearing white shirt open at collar, and black jacket.]]After Timothy Dalton retired from the Bond role in 1994, Eon turned to the actor they had considered after ''A View to a Kill'': [[Pierce Brosnan]].{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=168}} He was offered a three-film contract, with an option on a fourth;{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=186}} his salary for his first film, ''[[GoldenEye]]'', was $4 million, which rose to $16.5 million for his fourth and final outing, ''[[Die Another Day]]''.{{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|p=429}} Brosnan had first met Broccoli on the set of ''For Your Eyes Only'', when Brosnan's wife, [[Cassandra Harris]], was appearing in the film as Countess Lisl von Schlaf, and the couple lunched with Broccoli during filming.{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=137}} Brosnan went on to play a criminal-turned-private investigator in ''[[Remington Steele]]'' in the 1980s,{{sfn|Life Magazine|2012|p=55}} where he captured some of the traits of previous Bonds in playing the role: like Moore, he exemplified a high degree of suavity, elegance, charm and wit,{{sfn|Macintyre|2008|p=204}}{{sfn|Mizejewski|2004|p=75}}{{sfn|Charles|Clark|Hamilton-Selway|Morrison|2011|p=147}} but displayed a masculinity and grittiness on occasion reminiscent of Connery's Bond, both successfully "combine the character's Englishness with a classless internationalism that is highly knowing".{{sfn|Spicer|2003|p=186}} Andrew Spicer says that "Brosnan's frame carries the 'Armani look' with its refined understated Englishness, to perfection. His lithe, sinuous athleticism is well suited to the fast-paced action and state-of-the-art gadgetry that retains the series' core appeal".{{sfn|Spicer|2003|p=186}} James Chapman also considered Brosnan's appearance striking, saying the actor had "old-fashioned, darkly handsome matinee idol looks".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=214}} With Brosnan, the Bond writers knew that because of the changes in public attitudes, he could not be as overtly sexual and dominant over women as Connery's Bond, and was denounced by M in ''GoldenEye'' to be a "sexist, misogynist dinosaur, a relic of the Cold War".{{sfn|Spicer|2003|p=186}} Brosnan was seen by many as the quintessential James Bond in appearance and manner; displaying an air of coolness, elegance and a grace which made him believable as an international playboy, if not purely as an assassin. John G. Stackhouse for instance argues that it is preposterous that any man as strikingly handsome as Brosnan and Connery could be a secret agent, saying, "When Sean Connery or Pierce Brosnan enters a room, everyone notices. Thus it is ridiculous to suppose that James Bond, looking like that, could be a secret agent for longer than about two seconds".{{sfn|Stackhouse|2008|p=320}} Brosnan's Bond was introduced in ''GoldenEye''; James Chapman argues that the film works his portrayal of Bond into the history of the others in the series through the post-credits sequence use of the {{nowrap|[[Aston Martin DB5]]}}, previously seen in ''Goldfinger'' and ''Thunderball'', "thus immediately evoking the memory of [Sean] Connery".{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=220}} Brosnan's characterisation of Bond was seen by Jeremy Black as being "closer to the Fleming novels than Moore ... yet he is also lighter and less intense than Dalton".{{sfn|Black|2005|p=160}} Black also commented that the shift in character in the first three films reflected changing social opinions, with Bond not smoking.{{sfn|Black|2005|p=161}} Brosnan was clear he wanted to change Bond's smoking habit, saying "I don't give a damn about everyone's perception of the character: I think smoking causes [[cancer]] therefore he doesn't smoke",{{sfn|Barnes|Hearn|2001|p=186}} although he did smoke a Cuban cigar in ''Die Another Day''.{{sfn|Everett|2012|p=214}} Brosnan continued with the use of humour prevalent with other portrayals,{{sfn|Jütting|2007|p=50}} and provided a "mix of action and danger threaded through with the right amount of wit and humour";{{sfn|Simpson|2002|p=42}} Smith and Lavington saw the humour largely as puns that were "flippant, but not crass".{{sfn|Smith|Lavington|2002|p=242}} After four films in the role, Brosnan stated he wished to do one final Bond film. Although plans were made for a film to be released in 2004, negotiations stalled and Brosnan announced his intention to leave in July 2004.{{sfn|Moore|2012|p=165}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ Pierce Brosnan as James Bond in: |- ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:55px;" | Year ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top; width:225px;" | Film ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top;" | Salary $ (millions){{sfn|Block|Autrey Wilson|2010|pp=428–429}} |- ! scope="row" | 1995 | ''[[GoldenEye]]'' | 4.0 |- ! scope="row" | 1997 | ''[[Tomorrow Never Dies]]'' | 8.2 |- ! scope="row" | 1999 | ''{{sort|world|[[The World Is Not Enough]]}}'' | 12.4 |- ! scope="row" | 2002 | ''[[Die Another Day]]'' | 16.5 |} ===Daniel Craig: 2005–present=== [[File:Daniel Craig - Film Premiere "Spectre" 007 - on the Red Carpet in Berlin (22387409720) (cropped).jpg|upright|thumb|[[Daniel Craig]] at the Berlin premiere of ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]'' in October 2015.]] On 14 October 2005 Eon Productions, [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] and [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] announced at a press conference in London that [[Daniel Craig]] would be the sixth actor to portray Bond in the Eon series.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/oct/14/film.filmnews |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |title=Daniel Craig confirmed as 006th screen Bond |accessdate=13 September 2012 | date=14 October 2005}} A tuxedo- and lifejacket-clad Craig arrived via a [[Royal Navy]] speedboat.{{cite news|last=Baracaia|first=Alexa|title=Meet the new James Bond ... very shaken and stirred|newspaper=[[Evening Standard]]|date=14 October 2005|location=London|page=3}} Craig had based his acceptance of the role on the strength of the script for the first film, ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]''; he later recalled that "once I sat down and read the story, I just thought that I wanted to tell [it] ... I'm a big Bond fan, and I love what he represents".{{sfn|Cork|Stutz|2007|p=35}} Significant controversy followed the decision, with some critics and fans expressing doubt the producers had made the right choice. Throughout the entire production period, Internet campaigns such as danielcraigisnotbond.com expressed their dissatisfaction and threatened to boycott the film in protest.{{cite news|last=LaPorte|first=Nicole|title=Auds grow fond of 'short,' 'blond' Bond|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=27 November 2006|location=Los Angeles|page=3}} Craig, unlike previous actors, was not considered by the protesters to fit the tall, dark, handsome and charismatic image of Bond to which viewers had been accustomed.{{Cite news|title=Blond, James Blond |url=http://money.cnn.com/2006/11/08/commentary/mediabiz/index.htm |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=6 November 2006 |accessdate=13 September 2012 | first=Paul R. | last=La Monica}} Many disparagingly called him "James Blonde", believing the {{convert|5|ft|10|in|m|abbr=on}} blond-haired blue-eyed rugged Craig to be far fitting from the traditional tall, dark and suave actors who had earlier portrayed him. The ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' ran a front-page news story critical of Craig, with the headline, ''The Name's Bland – James Bland''.{{Cite news|last=Cummins |first=Fiona |title=The Name's Bland.. James Bland |work=[[Daily Mirror]] |location=London |date=15 October 2005 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/tm_objectid=16251427&method=full&siteid=94762&headline=the-name-s-bland---james-bland-name_page.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060414151815/http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/tm_objectid%3D16251427%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D94762%26headline%3Dthe-name-s-bland---james-bland-name_page.html |archivedate=14 April 2006 |accessdate=13 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=}} Craig first played Bond in the 2006 film ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'', an adaptation of Fleming's [[Casino Royale (novel)|novel of the same name]] and a reboot of the Eon series, which saw Bond earn his 00 status.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=242}} Despite the negative press on his appointment, Craig was widely praised by critics and former Bonds after the release of ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'', believing him to have been the first actor to truly nail Fleming's character in the book: [[Todd McCarthy]], reviewing the film for [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']], considered that "Craig comes closer to the author's original conception of this exceptionally long-lived male fantasy figure than anyone since early Sean Connery", and he went on to say that "Craig once and for all claims the character as his own", while [[Steven Spielberg]] called Craig "the perfect 21st-century Bond".{{sfn|Bouzereau|2006|p=148}} Paul Arendt, writing for the [[BBC]], agreed, observing that "Daniel Craig is not a good Bond. He's a ''great'' Bond. Specifically, he is 007 as conceived by Ian Fleming—a professional killing machine, a charming, cold-hearted patriot with a taste for luxury. Craig is the first actor to really nail 007's defining characteristic: he's an absolute swine". James Chapman commented on the realism and violence in the film noting that Bond is seen to seriously bleed for the first time in the series; Chapman also identified a number of violent scenes which make ''Casino Royale'' notable in the series.{{sfn|Chapman|2009|p=245}} In 2012 ''Skyfall'' was released: it was Craig's third outing as 007. Reviewing the film, [[Philip French]], writing in ''[[The Observer]]'', considered that Craig managed to "get out of the shadow of Connery", while the ''[[New Statesman]]'' thought that he had "relaxed into Bond without losing any steeliness". {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ Daniel Craig as James Bond in: |- ! scope="col" style="vertical-align:top;
